review.title: Surrogate Model of Multi-Period Flexibility from a Home Energy Management System
review.abstract: Near-future electric distribution grids operation will have to rely on demand-side flexibility, both by implementation of demand response strategies and by taking advantage of the intelligent management of increasingly common small-scale energy storage. Home energy management systems (HEMS) will play a crucial role on the flexibility provision to both system operators and market players like aggregators. Modeling multi-period flexibility from residential consumers (HEMS flexibility), such as battery storage and electric water heater, while complying with internal constraints (comfort levels, data privacy) and uncertainty is a complex task. This paper describes a computational method that is capable of efficiently define and learn the feasible flexibility set from controllable resources connected to a HEMS. An Evolutionary Particle Swarm Optimization (EPSO) algorithm is adopted and reshaped to derive a set of feasible temporal trajectories for the residential net-load, considering storage, flexible appliances, and predefined costumer preferences, as well as load and photovoltaic (PV) forecast uncertainty. A support vector data description (SVDD) algorithm is used to build models capable of classifying feasible and unfeasible HEMS operating trajectories upon request from an optimization/control algorithm operated by a DSO or market player.

metadata.title: Surrogate Model of Multi-Period Flexibility from a Home Energy Management System

sections.text: The operation of future power distribution grids will need to be based on demand-side flexibility, both by implementing demand response strategies and by leveraging the smart management of increasingly common small-scale energy storage systems. Home Energy Management Systems (HEMS) will play a critical role in providing flexibility to both system operators and market participants such as aggregators. Modelling flexibility over multiple time periods of residential consumers (HEMS flexibility), such as battery storage and electric hot water heaters, while respecting internal constraints (comfort level, privacy) and uncertainty is a complex task. This paper describes a computing methodology that is capable of efficiently defining and learning practicable flexibility from controllable resources associated with a HEMS. An evolutionary particle swarm optimization algorithm (EPSO) is adopted and redesigned to accommodate a range of workable load time models for consumer tractor and non-tractable household devices.
